criteria: Relevance to Safety and Violence Prevention:
descriptions: Demonstrates no understanding of information sources; presents inaccurate or irrelevant details.
Presents mostly inaccurate information from unreliable sources.
Presents some accurate information, but sources are questionable or not clearly identified.
Presents generally accurate information from identified sources, but some details may be lacking or incomplete.
Presents accurate and relevant information from credible sources; details are mostly complete and well-explained.
Presents highly accurate, comprehensive, and insightful information from diverse, credible sources; demonstrates a deep understanding.
Unable to identify or analyze sources.
Attempts to identify sources but shows no analysis or understanding of their relevance.
Identifies sources but provides a superficial analysis with limited understanding of their strengths or weaknesses.
Analyzes sources with some understanding of their relevance and credibility, but the analysis lacks depth.
Provides a thorough analysis of sources, demonstrating a good understanding of their strengths, weaknesses, and relevance.
Presents a sophisticated and critical analysis of sources, demonstrating a deep understanding of their biases, perspectives, and impact on safety and violence prevention.
Information and services are not relevant to safety and violence prevention.
Information and services have minimal relevance to safety and violence prevention.
Information and services are somewhat relevant, but the connection to safety and violence prevention is not clear.
Information and services are generally relevant to safety and violence prevention, but some connections are weak.
Information and services are clearly relevant and well-connected to safety and violence prevention strategies.
Information and services are highly relevant and effectively integrated into comprehensive safety and violence prevention strategies; demonstrates a clear understanding of their impact.
